newsitem.title: UK: UK lags other Europeans in EMU preparation - survey.
newsitem.headline: UK lags other Europeans in EMU preparation - survey.

text.p: Britain's top 350 companies are underestimating the scale of the information technology (IT) implications of European monetary union (EMU) compared with their counterparts in Germany and the Netherlands, a survey by European IT services group CMG Plc showed.
The survey revealed a large majority of 83 percent of Britain's top 350 financial directors are in favour of joining EMU with 60 percent believing the euro will come into being on January 1, 1999.
The survey of more than 200 top companies in the U.K. Germany and the Netherlands was conducted by Cititgate Technology for CMG in October 1996.
Only seven percent of U.K. finance directors thought EMU would have a very great impact on their IT systems in contrast to 53 percent in the Netherlands and 58 percent in Germany.
Industry estimates are that it could cost individual companies up to 30 million sterling to implement the necessary changes to systems to cope with the euro and VAT standardisation.
In the Netherlands 54 pecent of companies said they had started to prepare for EMU while in Germany the figure was 45 percent. Only 31 percent in the U.K. said they had started.
"What's so frightening about these results is that industry in the U.K. is woefully unprepared for the real implications of EMU," said CMG's U.K. chairman Ian Taylor.
"They're far more in favour than most commentators have said until now but don't understand how much it will cost in terms of changes to their IT systems and to turn it into reality."
